title: 107_s1035
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Preservation Act". It includes findings related to the Great Lakes. Congress finds that the Great Lakes are precious public natural resources crucial to the economies of the Great Lakes States, containing 1/5 of the world's fresh water supply and serving as a vital source of safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 is a voluntary international agreement that provides a procedural framework for notice and consultation regarding water diversion in the Great Lakes basin. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 is a voluntary international agreement that guides decisions on water diversion in the Great Lakes basin, emphasizing conservation and protection of water resources. Decision-making regarding Great Lakes water is to be managed by the Governors of the Great Lakes States. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 is a voluntary international agreement that guides decisions on water diversion in the Great Lakes basin, managed by the Governors of the Great Lakes States. SEC. 3 defines key terms. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Bulk fresh water" is fresh water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" includes water from specific lakes, interconnecting waterways, and tributaries. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada, while the term "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. Bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin shall not be exported from the United States. This provision will end when a Congress-approved mechanism for water decisions is in place. Congress suggests a US-Canada agreement to uphold the moratorium. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation. Lighthouses in the region are historically significant but face neglect. A study will be conducted to preserve them within 3 years. The future of Great Lakes lighthouses is uncertain due to neglect and deterioration. A study will be conducted within 3 years to identify options for preservation, reviewing National Park Service programs and consulting with historical associations and preservation agencies in the region. The future of Great Lakes lighthouses is uncertain due to neglect and deterioration. A study will be conducted within 3 years to identify options for preservation, consulting with State and local historical associations, historic preservation agencies, the Commandant of the Coast Guard, and other appropriate entities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funding.
